text:
Present your argument to your neighbor,
but do not reveal another person’s secret.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Otherwise, when he hears about it, he will humiliate you,
and his evil report about you will never disappear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like golden apples in silver settings,
so is a word spoken at the right time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a gold ring and a fine gold ornament,
so is constructive criticism to the ear of one who listens.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like the coolness of snow on a harvest day,
so is a trustworthy messenger to those who send him:
He refreshes his masters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a dense fog or a dust storm,
so is a person who brags about a gift that he does not give.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With patience you can persuade a ruler,
and a soft tongue can break bones.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When you find honey, eat only as much as you need.
Otherwise, you will have too much and vomit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not set foot in your neighbor’s house too often.
Otherwise, he will see too much of you and hate you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a club and a sword and a sharp arrow,
so is a person who gives false testimony against his neighbor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a broken tooth and a lame foot,
so is confidence in an unfaithful person in a time of crisis.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like taking off a coat on a cold day
or pouring vinegar on baking soda,
so is singing songs to one who has an evil heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If your enemy is hungry, give him some food to eat,
and if he is thirsty, give him some water to drink.
speaker: Narrator

text:
In this way you will make him feel guilty and ashamed,
and the Lord will reward you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As the north wind brings rain,
so a whispering tongue brings angry looks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to live on a corner of a roof
than to share a home with a quarreling woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like cold water to a thirsty soul,
so is good news from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a muddied spring and a polluted well,
so is a righteous person who gives in to a wicked person.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Eating too much honey is not good,
and searching for honor is not honorable.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a city broken into and left without a wall,
so is a person who lacks self-control.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like snow in summertime and rain at harvest time,
so honor is not right for a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a fluttering sparrow,
like a darting swallow,
so a hastily spoken curse does not come to rest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A whip is for the horse,
a bridle is for the donkey,
and a rod is for the backs of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not answer a fool with his own stupidity,
or you will be like him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Answer a fool with his own stupidity,
or he will think he is wise.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever uses a fool to send a message
cuts off his own feet and brings violence upon himself.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a lame person’s limp legs,
so is a proverb in the mouths of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like tying a stone to a sling,
so is giving honor to a fool.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a thorn stuck in a drunk’s hand,
so is a proverb in the mouths of fools.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like many people who destroy everything,
so is one who hires fools or drifters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a dog goes back to its vomit,
so a fool repeats his stupidity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you met a person who thinks he is wise?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lazy person says,
“There’s a ferocious lion out on the road!
There’s a lion loose in the streets!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a door turns on its hinges,
so the lazy person turns on his bed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lazy person puts his fork in his food.
He wears himself out as he brings it back to his mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text: A lazy person thinks he is wiser than seven people who give a sensible answer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like grabbing a dog by the ears,
so is a bystander who gets involved in someone else’s quarrel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Like a madman who shoots flaming arrows, arrows, and death,
speaker: Narrator

text: so is the person who tricks his neighbor and says, “I was only joking!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without wood a fire goes out,
and without gossip a quarrel dies down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As charcoal fuels burning coals and wood fuels fire,
so a quarrelsome person fuels a dispute.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of a gossip are swallowed greedily,
and they go down into a person’s innermost being.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a clay pot covered with cheap silver,
so is smooth talk that covers up an evil heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is filled with hate disguises it with his speech,
but inside he holds on to deceit.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When he talks charmingly, do not trust him
because of the seven disgusting things in his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
His hatred is deceitfully hidden,
but his wickedness will be revealed to the community.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it.
Whoever rolls a stone will have it roll back on him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lying tongue hates its victims,
and a flattering mouth causes ruin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not brag about tomorrow,
because you do not know what another day may bring.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Praise should come from another person
and not from your own mouth,
from a stranger and not from your own lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A stone is heavy, and sand weighs a lot,
but annoyance caused by a stubborn fool is heavier than both.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Anger is cruel, and fury is overwhelming,
but who can survive jealousy?
speaker: Narrator

text: Open criticism is better than unexpressed love.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wounds made by a friend are intended to help,
but an enemy’s kisses are too much to bear.
speaker: Narrator

text:
One who is full despises honey,
but to one who is hungry,
even bitter food tastes sweet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a bird wandering from its nest,
so is a husband wandering from his home.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Perfume and incense make the heart glad,
but the sweetness of a friend is a fragrant forest.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not abandon your friend or your father’s friend.
Do not go to a relative’s home when you are in trouble.
A neighbor living nearby is better than a relative far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be wise, my son, and make my heart glad
so that I can answer anyone who criticizes me.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Sensible people foresee trouble and hide.
Gullible people go ahead and suffer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hold on to the garment of one who guarantees a stranger’s loan,
and hold responsible the person
who makes a loan in behalf of a foreigner.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever blesses his friend early in the morning with a loud voice—
his blessing is considered a curse.
speaker: Narrator

text: Constantly dripping water on a rainy day is like a quarreling woman.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever can control her can control the wind.
He can even pick up olive oil with his right hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As iron sharpens iron,
so one person sharpens the wits of another.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever takes care of a fig tree can eat its fruit,
and whoever protects his master is honored.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As a face is reflected in water,
so a person is reflected by his heart.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hell and decay are never satisfied,
and a person’s eyes are never satisfied.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The crucible is for refining silver and the smelter for gold,
but a person is tested by the praise given to him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you crush a stubborn fool in a mortar with a pestle along with grain,
even then his stupidity will not leave him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be fully aware of the condition of your flock,
and pay close attention to your herds.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Wealth is not forever.
Nor does a crown last from one generation to the next.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When grass is cut short, the tender growth appears,
and vegetables are gathered on the hills.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Lambs will provide you with clothing,
and the money from the male goats will buy a field.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There will be enough goat milk to feed you,
to feed your family,
and to keep your servant girls alive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A wicked person flees when no one is chasing him,
but righteous people are as bold as lions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a country is in revolt, it has many rulers,
but only with a person who has understanding and knowledge
will it last a long time.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A poor person who oppresses poorer people
is like a driving rain that leaves no food.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Those who abandon God’s teachings praise wicked people,
but those who follow God’s teachings oppose wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Evil people do not understand justice,
but those who seek the Lord understand everything.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Better to be a poor person who has integrity
than to be rich and double-dealing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever follows God’s teachings is a wise son.
Whoever associates with gluttons disgraces his father.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever becomes wealthy through unfair loans and interest
collects them for the one who is kind to the poor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Surely the prayer of someone who refuses
to listen to God’s teachings is disgusting.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever leads decent people into evil will fall into his own pit,
but innocent people will inherit good things.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A rich person is wise in his own eyes,
but a poor person with understanding sees right through him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When righteous people triumph, there is great glory,
but when wicked people rise, people hide themselves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever covers over his sins does not prosper.
Whoever confesses and abandons them receives compassion.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blessed is the one who is always fearful of sin,
but whoever is hard-hearted falls into disaster.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Like a roaring lion and a charging bear,
so a wicked ruler is a threat to poor people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A leader without understanding taxes his people heavily,
but those who hate unjust gain will live longer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person burdened with the guilt of murder
will be a fugitive down to his grave.
No one will help him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever lives honestly will be safe.
Whoever lives dishonestly will fall all at once.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever works his land will have plenty to eat.
Whoever chases unrealistic dreams will have plenty of nothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A trustworthy person has many blessings,
but anyone in a hurry to get rich will not escape punishment.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Showing partiality is not good,
because some people will turn on you even for a piece of bread.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A stingy person is in a hurry to get rich,
not realizing that poverty is about to overtake him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever criticizes people will be more highly regarded in the future
than the one who flatters with his tongue.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The one who robs his father or his mother
and says, “It isn’t wrong!” is a companion to a vandal.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A greedy person stirs up a fight,
but whoever trusts the Lord prospers.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever trusts his own heart is a fool.
Whoever walks in wisdom will survive.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever gives to the poor lacks nothing.
Whoever ignores the poor receives many curses.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When wicked people rise, people hide.
When they die, righteous people increase.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who will not bend after many warnings
will suddenly be broken beyond repair.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When righteous people increase, the people of God rejoice,
but when a wicked person rules, everybody groans.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who loves wisdom makes his father happy,
but one who pays prostitutes wastes his wealth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
By means of justice, a king builds up a country,
but a person who confiscates religious contributions tears it down.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person who flatters his neighbor
is spreading a net for him to step into.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To an evil person sin is bait in a trap,
but a righteous person runs away from it and is glad.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A righteous person knows the just cause of the poor.
A wicked person does not understand this.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mockers create an uproar in a city,
but wise people turn away anger.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a wise person goes to court with a stubborn fool,
he may rant and rave,
but there is no peace and quiet.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Bloodthirsty people hate an innocent person,
but decent people seek to protect his life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A fool expresses all his emotions,
but a wise person controls them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If a ruler pays attention to lies,
all his servants become wicked.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A poor person and an oppressor have this in common:
The Lord gives both of them sight.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When a king judges the poor with honesty,
his throne will always be secure.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A spanking and a warning produce wisdom,
but an undisciplined child disgraces his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
When wicked people increase, crime increases,
but righteous people will witness their downfall.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Correct your son, and he will give you peace of mind.
He will bring delight to your soul.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Without prophetic vision people run wild,
but blessed are those who follow God’s teachings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A slave cannot be disciplined with words.
He will not respond, though he may understand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Have you met a person who is quick to answer?
There is more hope for a fool than for him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Pamper a slave from childhood,
and later he will be ungrateful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An angry person stirs up a fight,
and a hothead does much wrong.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s pride will humiliate him,
but a humble spirit gains honor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Whoever is a thief’s partner hates his own life.
He will not testify under oath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A person’s fear sets a trap for him,
but one who trusts the Lord is safe.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Many seek an audience with a ruler,
but justice for humanity comes from the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
An unjust person is disgusting to righteous people.
A decent person is disgusting to wicked people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The words of Agur, son of Jakeh. Agur’s prophetic revelation.
This man’s declaration:
“I’m weary, O God.
I’m weary and worn out, O God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I’m more like a dumb animal than a human being.
I don’t even have human understanding.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I haven’t learned wisdom.
I don’t have knowledge of the Holy One.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who has gone up to heaven and come down?
Who has gathered the wind in the palm of his hand?
Who has wrapped water in a garment?
Who has set up the earth from one end to the other?
What is his name or the name of his son?
Certainly, you must know!
speaker: Narrator

text:
“All of God’s word has proven to be true.
He is a shield to those who come to him for protection.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Do not add to his words,
or he will reprimand you, and you will be found to be a liar.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“I’ve asked you for two things.
Don’t keep them from me before I die:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Keep vanity and lies far away from me.
Don’t give me either poverty or riches.
Feed me only the food I need,
speaker: Narrator

text:
or I may feel satisfied and deny you
and say, ‘Who is the Lord?’
or I may become poor and steal
and give the name of my God a bad reputation.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Do not slander a slave to his master.
The slave will curse you,
and you will be found guilty.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
A certain kind of person curses his father
and does not bless his mother.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A certain kind of person thinks he is pure
but is not washed from his own feces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A certain kind of person looks around arrogantly
and is conceited.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A certain kind of person,
whose teeth are like swords
and whose jaws are like knives,
devours oppressed people from the earth
and people from among humanity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The bloodsucking leech has two daughters—“Give!” and “Give!”
Three things are never satisfied.
Four never say, “Enough!”:
speaker: Narrator

text:
the grave,
a barren womb,
a land that never gets enough water,
a fire that does not say, “Enough!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
The eye that makes fun of a father and hates to obey a mother
will be plucked out by ravens in the valley and eaten by young vultures.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Three things are too amazing to me,
even four that I cannot understand:
speaker: Narrator

text:
an eagle making its way through the sky,
a snake making its way over a rock,
a ship making its way through high seas,
a man making his way with a virgin.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is the way of a woman who commits adultery:
She eats, wipes her mouth,
and says, “I haven’t done anything wrong!”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Three things cause the earth to tremble,
even four it cannot bear up under:
speaker: Narrator

text:
a slave when he becomes king,
a godless fool when he is filled with food,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a woman who is unloved when she gets married,
a maid when she replaces her mistress.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Four things on earth are small,
yet they are very wise:
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ants are not a strong species,
yet they store their food in summer.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rock badgers are not a mighty species,
yet they make their home in the rocks.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Locusts have no king,
yet all of them divide into swarms by instinct.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A lizard you can hold in your hands,
yet it can even be found in royal palaces.
speaker: Narrator

text:
There are three things that walk with dignity,
even four that march with dignity:
speaker: Narrator

text: a lion, mightiest among animals, which turns away from nothing,
speaker: Narrator

text:
a strutting rooster,
a male goat,
a king at the head of his army.
speaker: Narrator

text:
If you are such a godless fool as to honor yourself,
or if you scheme,
you had better put your hand over your mouth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
As churning milk produces butter
and punching a nose produces blood,
so stirring up anger  produces a fight.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sayings of King Lemuel, a prophetic revelation, used by his mother to discipline him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“What, my son?
What, son to whom I gave birth?
What, son of my prayers?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Don’t give your strength to women
or your power to those who ruin kings.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“It is not for kings, Lemuel.
It is not for kings to drink wine or for rulers to crave liquor.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Otherwise, they drink and forget what they have decreed
and change the standard of justice for all oppressed people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Give liquor to a person who is dying
and wine to one who feels resentful.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Such a person drinks
and forgets his poverty
and does not remember his trouble anymore.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Speak out for the one who cannot speak,
for the rights of those who are doomed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Speak out,
judge fairly,
and defend the rights of oppressed and needy people.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Who can find a wife with a strong character?
She is worth far more than jewels.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her husband trusts her with all his heart,
and he does not lack anything good.
speaker: Narrator

text: She helps him and never harms him all the days of her life.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“She seeks out wool and linen with care
and works with willing hands.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She is like merchant ships.
She brings her food from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She wakes up while it is still dark
and gives food to her family
and portions of food to her female slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“She picks out a field and buys it.
She plants a vineyard from the profits she has earned.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She puts on strength like a belt
and goes to work with energy.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She sees that she is making a good profit.
Her lamp burns late at night.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“She puts her hands on the distaff,
and her fingers hold a spindle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She opens her hands to oppressed people
and stretches them out to needy people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She does not fear for her family when it snows
because her whole family
has a double layer of clothing.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She makes quilts for herself.
Her clothes are made of linen and purple cloth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Her husband is known at the city gates
when he sits with the leaders of the land.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“She makes linen garments and sells them
and delivers belts to the merchants.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She dresses with strength and nobility,
and she smiles at the future.
speaker: Narrator

text:
“She speaks with wisdom,
and on her tongue there is tender instruction.
speaker: Narrator

text:
She keeps a close eye on the conduct of her family,
and she does not eat the bread of idleness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Her children and her husband
stand up and bless her.
In addition, he sings her praises, by saying,
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Many women have done noble work,
but you have surpassed them all!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
“Charm is deceptive, and beauty evaporates,
but a woman who has the fear of the Lord should be praised.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Reward her for what she has done,
and let her achievements praise her at the city gates.”
speaker: Narrator
